questions.text: A 67-year-old woman in the intensive care unit awakes at night and mistakes her intravenous pole for a family member coming for a visit. Which term best describes the perceptual problem?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Illusion Misinterpretation of a normal stimulus . Illusions are distortions of real images or sensations.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Hallucinations are not based on real images or sensations. They are perceptions in absence of the stimulus. Option: C & D. - Micropsia and macropsia are the misperceptions of objects being smaller or larger than they are.

questions.text: A patient comes to the doctor and says he feels pain in his head when he hears people coughing. Which type of hallucination is this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reflex hallucination Reflex hallucination is a hallucinatory form of synesthesia in which a stimulus in one sensory modality produces a hallucination in another sensory modality . For example, a patient felt a pain in her head (somatic hallucination) when she heard other people sneeze (the stimulus) and was convinced that sneezing caused the pain.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Functional Hallucination - In this stimulus one sensory modality produces hallucination in the same sensory modality . For example, a patient reported that whenever he heard the sound of tap water (stimulus in auditory modality) he would start hearing voices of god (hallucinations in auditory modality). Option: C. Auditory Hallucination - False perception of sound , usually voices, but also other noises, such as music. Option: D. Somatic Hallucination - Hallucination involving the perception of a physical experience localized within the body.

questions.text: Match the following perception disorders along with their associated disease. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1=b,2=c, 3=a Hallucinations are perceptions in the absence of stimuli to account for them. Visual and auditory hallucinations are commonly seen in patients with Schizophrenia . Tactile hallucinations are common in cocaine intake, and Delirium tremens . Olfactory hallucinations are common in temporal lobe epilepsy .

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with bipolar disorder, who is currently in a manic state, responds to interview questions with a flight of ideas. The patient is asked how she got to the hospital. Which of the following statements by the patient is the best example of this form of thought disturbance?

options.label: B
options.text: “I was reading a great book at home and, after I finished it, I drove here myself.”

options.label: C
options.text: “I like history books and I was reading one at home today while eating fish.”

options.label: D
options.text: “I started driving but was thinking about my history. History books are great. I once wrote a paper on Alexander the Great. I do well in college.”

questions.correct_answer: D. “I started driving but was thinking about my history. History books are great. I once wrote a paper on Alexander the Great. I do well in college.”
questions.explanation:
Solution:

“I started driving but was thinking about my history. History books are great. I once wrote a paper on Alexander the Great. I do well in college.” Flight of ideas is a non-goal-directed speech that reflects a rapid jumping of thoughts through a series of weakly related ideas .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Is a goal-directed, linear statement. Option: B. Is an example of circumstantiality. Option: C. Is an example of tangentiality.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy bought by his mother as he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons, and says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon”. He also thinks that the thought is equal to the deed, that wishing a person dead will make it happen, What is this example of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Magical thinking This is a case of Magical Thinking . Persons believe that merely by thinking about an event in the external world they can cause the event to occur without intermediate physical actions. This feeling causes them to fear having an aggressive thoughts.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Auditory hallucination- patient hears voices without a stimulus Option: B. Illusion - misinterpretation of a normal stimulus. Option: D. Functional hallucination - In this stimulus one sensory modality produces a hallucination in the same sensory modality . For example, a patient reported that whenever he heard the sound of tap water (stimulus in auditory modality) he would start hearing voices of god (hallucinations in auditory modality)

questions.text: Match the following perception disorders accordingly. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1=d, 2=c, 3=a, 4=b Misperception of stimuli is an illusion. Eg. Hearing the wind rustle through the trees outside one’s bedroom and thinking a name is being called is an illusion. Hallucinations are perceptions in the absence of stimuli to account for them. Auditory hallucinations are the hallucinations most frequently encountered in the psychiatric setting. Other hallucinations can include visual, tactile, olfactory, and gustatory (taste). Depersonalization is a feeling that one is not oneself or that something has changed. Derealization is a feeling that one’s environment has changed in some strange way that is difficult to describe.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female was bought by her parents with complaints of smelling burnt charcoal in the past few days when there is nothing nearby. She had similar episodes 1-2 times a day. There is no loss of consciousness, No weakness following the episodes. On examination vitals are normal. An EEG was performed on the patient which is given below. The type of hallucination present in the given condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Olfactory The given image depicts temporal lobe epilepsy . Olfactory hallucinations are common in temporal lobe epilepsy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A & B. Auditory and visual hallucinations are common in Schizophrenia. Option: D. Tactile hallucination is common in cocaine intake, and Delirium tremens.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a complaint of something crawling under his skin since yesterday. He bought a matchbox with a skin scraping as proof of the insects crawling under his skin. On further history evaluation, the patient admitted of substance abuse from the following plant seen in the image. On examination, vitals were Bp.150/90, pulse 86/ min, and Afebrile. The most common type of hallucination seen in this substance use disorder is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tactile The given image is of the coca plant from which cocaine is derived. Tactile hallucinations are common in cocaine intake, and Delirium tremens .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A & B. Auditory and visual hallucinations are common in Schizophrenia. Option: C. Olfactory hallucinations are commonly seen in temporal lobe epilepsy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, at a school anniversary celebration, can’t describe vividly what Martians may look like. Which of the following is true about this imagery? The imagery is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A fantasy Imagery is not a perception because there is no stimulus involved and no object perceived ; it is essentially a fantasy. Imagery refers to images produced voluntarily with complete insight that they are a mental phenomenon and not of external origin . Imageries lack the ‘objective’ quality of hallucinations and normal sense perceptions .

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady reports hearing voices in her head. Which of the following differences between hallucination and pseudohallucination is true?

options.label: A
options.text: In true hallucinations insight is often retained

options.label: B
options.text: True hallucinations are often identified to be originating from self

options.label: C
options.text: True hallucinations occur in subjective space

options.label: D
options.text: True hallucinations are sought in other modalities by the patient

questions.correct_answer: D. True hallucinations are sought in other modalities by the patient
questions.explanation:
Solution:

True hallucinations are sought in other modalities by the patient Hallucinations have several important qualities which are essential in differentiating them from other mental phenomena. Hallucinations take place at the same time and in the same space as other perceptions, for example ‘an angel is standing in the corner of my room’.

Highyeild:

This is different from fantasy or imagery which takes place in a subjective space . They are experienced as sensations – not as thoughts – in contrast to obsessional images. The percept has all the qualities of a real-world object , that is a patient when hallucinating believes that the percept can be experienced in other modalities too, like a real object which can be seen, felt, smelt, and heard. Pseudohallucinations are used to describe hallucination-like experiences with retained insight (so it is not sought in other modalities of perception). It takes place in a subjective space , for example ‘a voice inside my head’.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an elementary hallucination?

options.label: B
options.text: Visions of small mice in a minutia

options.label: D
options.text: Voices speaking in an unknown language

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flashes of light Elementary hallucinations are unstructured hallucinations that are seen in acute organic states . They are composed of sounds or flashes without being fully formed .

Highyeild:

Elementary hallucinations can precede the development of fully formed hallucinations , especially in alcoholic hallucinosis. The flashes of lights are also called phosphenes . Words such as ‘go’ are meaningful and so cannot be a part of the elementary hallucination.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Extracampine hallucination?

options.label: A
options.text: A 47-year-old man hears voices coming from the South Pole

options.label: B
options.text: A 32-year-old man hears a voice coming from his left knee

options.label: C
options.text: A 53-year-old lady sees a devil’s tail hanging on a hook

options.label: D
options.text: A 30-year-old man sees an angel without a face

questions.correct_answer: A. A 47-year-old man hears voices coming from the South Pole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A 47-year-old man hears voices coming from the South Pole Extracampine hallucinations are hallucinations that occur outside the normal field of perception , for example, images seen behind your back, under your sternum, or hearing voices from Inverness, etc. (if you are not living in Inverness, of course!). They occur in schizophrenia, epilepsy , and also in hypnagogic hallucinations of healthy people – so they are not diagnostically important.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. It is an example of auditory hallucination. Option: C. It is an example of visual hallucination/illusion(extra details required). Option: D. It is an example of visual hallucination.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female is brought with complaints that she can hear voices whenever she heard the noise of water running through a tap. Which kind of hallucination she is going through?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Functional hallucination In functional hallucinations, an external stimulus provokes a hallucination, and both hallucination and stimulus are in the same modality but individually perceived, for example, voices are heard simultaneously whenever the noise of water running through a kitchen tap is heard. They are not illusions , as the stimulus is perceived appropriately (noise of water), but in addition, there is another perception (voices) without an appropriate object.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. If hallucinations in one modality are provoked reflexively by a stimulus in another modality , for example seeing an angel whenever listening to music, then this is called reflex hallucination . Option: B. The phenomenon of perceiving a stimulus of one modality in a different modality (may be single or multiple modalities) is called synesthesia , for example tasting the music, hearing colors, and smelling voices. Option: D. Extracampine hallucinations are experienced o utside the limits of the sensory field (outside the visual field or beyond the range of audibility). Eg. “I know that there is someone behind me on the right all the time; he moves when I move’, ‘I keep on hearing them talking about my disease down in the post office’ (half a mile away).
